title: About
text:
About this blog
Hi, I’m Smriti Trivedi, a student at the University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign, studying Information Science + Data Science with a CS minor. Beyond academics, I enjoy flying, horse riding, and coding. This blog is where I share my thoughts and ideas—blending my love for technology and creativity. Thanks for stopping by!

title: Electric Vehicle
text:
This is a post with executable code.
The transition to electric vehicles (EVs) is key to addressing climate change 
and reducing fossil fuel reliance. This dataset from the Washington State 
Department of Licensing highlights registration trends for battery electric 
(BEVs) and plug-in hybrid vehicles (PHEVs). It aids in understanding adoption
patterns, infrastructure needs, and clean energy effectiveness, policymakers,
businesses, and consumers toward sustainable mobility.

data url: https://catalog.data.gov/dataset/electric-vehicle-population-data
photo: https://unsplash.com/photos/black-and-silver-car-steering-wheel-YhXlYJYlr3c

library(ggplot2)
library(readr)


library(dplyr)


Attaching package: 'dplyr'


The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':

    filter, lag


The following objects are masked from 'package:base':

    intersect, setdiff, setequal, union

file_path <- "data/Cleaned_Electric_Vehicle_Population_Data.csv"
ev_data <- read_csv(file_path)

Rows: 216772 Columns: 6


── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr (4): Make, Model, Electric_Vehicle_Type, Clean_Alternative_Fuel_Vehicle
dbl (2): Year, Vehicle_ID

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.


The dataset contains over 200,000 records of electric vehicle registrations 
in Washington State.

head(ev_data)

# A tibble: 6 × 6
   Year Make       Model Electric_Vehicle_Type Clean_Alternative_Fu…¹ Vehicle_ID
  <dbl> <chr>      <chr> <chr>                 <chr>                       <dbl>
1  2013 NISSAN     LEAF  Battery Electric Veh… Clean Alternative Fue…  125450447
2  2019 TESLA      MODE… Battery Electric Veh… Clean Alternative Fue…  101662900
3  2021 VOLKSWAGEN ID.4  Battery Electric Veh… Eligibility unknown a…  272118717
4  2017 TOYOTA     PRIU… Plug-in Hybrid Elect… Not eligible due to l…  349372929
5  2016 FORD       C-MAX Plug-in Hybrid Elect… Not eligible due to l…  171625653
6  2020 TESLA      MODE… Battery Electric Veh… Clean Alternative Fue…  127104078
# ℹ abbreviated name: ¹​Clean_Alternative_Fuel_Vehicle



summary(ev_data)

      Year          Make              Model           Electric_Vehicle_Type
 Min.   :1999   Length:216772      Length:216772      Length:216772        
 1st Qu.:2020   Class :character   Class :character   Class :character     
 Median :2022   Mode  :character   Mode  :character   Mode  :character     
 Mean   :2021                                                              
 3rd Qu.:2023                                                              
 Max.   :2025                                                              
 Clean_Alternative_Fuel_Vehicle   Vehicle_ID       
 Length:216772                  Min.   :     4385  
 Class :character               1st Qu.:196232753  
 Mode  :character               Median :244031206  
                                Mean   :230447917  
                                3rd Qu.:264907023  
                                Max.   :479254772  



ev_type_distribution <- ev_data %>%
  group_by(Electric_Vehicle_Type) %>%
  summarize(Count = n())

ggplot(ev_type_distribution, aes(x = reorder(Electric_Vehicle_Type, -Count), y = Count)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity", fill = "darkgreen") +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(title = "Distribution of Electric Vehicle Types",
       x = "Vehicle Type", y = "Count")








The majority of registrations are for Battery Electric Vehicles (BEVs), 
indicating a strong preference for fully electric solutions over hybrids.

if ("Year" %in% colnames(ev_data)) {
  ev_trends <- ev_data %>%
    group_by(Year) %>%
    summarize(Count = n())

  ggplot(ev_trends, aes(x = Year, y = Count)) +
    geom_line(color = "darkgreen") +
    theme_minimal() +
    labs(title = "Trends in Electric Vehicle Registrations",
         x = "Year", y = "Count")
}








A steady increase in EV registrations is observed, particularly post-2020, 
coinciding with growing environmental awareness and advancements in EV 
technology.

ev_model_analysis <- ev_data %>%
  group_by(Make) %>%
  summarize(Count = n()) %>%
  arrange(desc(Count)) %>%
  head(10)
ggplot(ev_model_analysis, aes(x = Make, y = Count)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity", fill = "darkgreen") +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(title = "Top 10 Electric Vehicle Models",
       x = "Make", y = "Count")








Tesla dominates the market. Other vehicles come from Nissan (Leaf) and Chevrolet (Bolt).

ev_model_analysis <- ev_data %>%
  group_by(Model) %>%
  summarize(Count = n()) %>%
  arrange(desc(Count)) %>%
  head(10)
ggplot(ev_model_analysis, aes(x = reorder(Model, -Count), y = Count)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity", fill = "darkgreen") +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(title = "Top 10 Electric Vehicle Models",
       x = "Model", y = "Count")








Tesla's Model 3 and Model Y lead registrations.
The visualizations confirm the dominance of BEVs in Washington State's electric 
vehicle population. The bar chart showcasing the distribution of EV types 
highlights the public's  clear inclination towards BEVs. This preference is 
driven by their lower emissions and decreasing costs. Temporal analysis 
demonstrates exponential growth in EV registrations.  This growth is especially noticeable in recent years. It suggests the presence of effective policy 
incentives and increased consumer confidence. The analysis of the top 10 EV 
models underscores the strong influence of Tesla on the market. This influence 
reflects Tesla's brand strength and innovation.
Sources

State of Washington. (2024). Electric Vehicle Population Data [Dataset]. Department of 
Licensing. Retrieved from https://data.wa.gov/d/f6w7-q2d2

title: Renewable energy
text:
This is a post with executable code.
Renewable energy is a critical focus in addressing climate change. The transition to sustainable energy sources like solar, wind, and hydropower ensures both environmental and economic benefits. Analyzing global data helps us understand trends, adoption rates, and areas of improvement.

library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)


Attaching package: 'dplyr'


The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':

    filter, lag


The following objects are masked from 'package:base':

    intersect, setdiff, setequal, union

library(tidyverse)

── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.1
✔ lubridate 1.9.3     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
✔ purrr     1.0.2     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ readr     2.1.5     


── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors



data <- read.csv("data/Renewable_Energy.csv")

The first few countries are Advanced Economics, which does not make sense. Africa is also listed as a country.
The dataset was cleaned and transformed for analysis. It contains time-series data, categorized by countries, technologies, and energy types (e.g., renewable and non-renewable).

data_long <- data %>%
  pivot_longer(cols = starts_with("F"), names_to = "Year", values_to = "Value") %>%
  mutate(Year = as.numeric(gsub("F", "", Year)))

Reshaping data for visualization, converting yearly columns into a long format.

renewables <- data_long %>%
  filter(Energy_Type == "Total Renewable" & Indicator == "Electricity Generation")

Filtering data to focus on renewable electricity generation.

renewables %>%
  filter(Country %in% c("United States", "India", "Germany")) %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = Year, y = Value, color = Country)) +
  geom_line(size = 1) +
  labs(title = "Renewable Electricity Generation Over Time",
       x = "Year",
       y = "Generation (GWh)") +
  theme_minimal()

Warning: Using `size` aesthetic for lines was deprecated in ggplot2 3.4.0.
ℹ Please use `linewidth` instead.


Warning: Removed 12 rows containing missing values or values outside the scale range
(`geom_line()`).









The United States demonstrates steady growth in renewable energy. This growth is particularly driven by significant wind and hydropower contributions. Recent boosts in solar and infrastructure investments further enhance this trend. India shows rapid acceleration in renewable capacity. This is primarily due to solar and wind energy, aided by ambitious government targets for 2030. Germany has a mature renewable energy sector and maintains consistent output from wind and solar. Hydropower also plays a key role in stabilizing its energy mix. The graph highlights these trends clearly. The U.S. dominates in generation, while India is on a sharp upward trajectory. Germany continues to maintain steady growth. Accurate data handling is critical to monitoring this global transition.

renewables %>%
  group_by(Technology) %>%
  summarise(Total = sum(Value, na.rm = TRUE)) %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = Technology, y = Total)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity", fill = "darkgreen") +
  labs(title = "Total Renewable Energy Generation by Technology",
       x = "Technology",
       y = "Total Generation (GWh)") +
  theme_minimal()








Hydropower remains the largest contributor to renewable energy. This is due to its large-scale capacity and widespread use. Wind energy follows, providing substantial output. Solar energy is rapidly growing but still lags behind wind and hydropower. Bioenergy contributes minimally. However, it remains a key component of the renewable energy mix.
Renewables are on the rise, but the pace varies significantly between nations and technologies. Wind and Hydropower energy are leading the renewable revolution.
Source
Dataset: https://www.kaggle.com/datasets/pinuto/global-energy-generation-and-capacity-imf
Image: https://unsplash.com/photos/water-dam-under-white-and-blue-skies-FUeb2npsblQ

title: Welcome To My Blog
text:
This is the first post in a Quarto blog. Welcome!
 Welcome to my blog! Here, I explore how electric vehicles and renewable energy are shaping a sustainable future. Discover how these technologies are transforming transportation, energy, and the fight against climate change. Let’s rethink what’s possible (with data).
